text: There was a man in the land of Uz, whose name was Job; and that man was perfect and upright, and one that feared God, and eschewed evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there were born unto him seven sons and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: His substance also was seven thousand sheep, and three thousand camels, and five hundred yoke of oxen, and five hundred she asses, and a very great household; so that this man was the greatest of all the men of the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: And his sons went and feasted in their houses, every one his day; and sent and called for their three sisters to eat and to drink with them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it was so, when the days of their feasting were gone about, that Job sent and sanctified them, and rose up early in the morning, and offered burnt offerings according to the number of them all: for Job said, It may be that my sons have sinned, and cursed God in their hearts. Thus did Job continually.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan came also among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said unto Satan, Whence comest thou? Then Satan answered the Lord, and said, From going to and fro in the earth, and from walking up and down in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said unto Satan, Hast thou considered my servant Job, that there is none like him in the earth, a perfect and an upright man, one that feareth God, and escheweth evil?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Satan answered the Lord, and said, Doth Job fear God for nought?
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast not thou made an hedge about him, and about his house, and about all that he hath on every side? thou hast blessed the work of his hands, and his substance is increased in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: But put forth thine hand now, and touch all that he hath, and he will curse thee to thy face.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said unto Satan, Behold, all that he hath is in thy power; only upon himself put not forth thine hand. So Satan went forth from the presence of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there was a day when his sons and his daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother’s house:
speaker: Narrator

text: and there came a messenger unto Job, and said, The oxen were plowing, and the asses feeding beside them:
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Sabeans fell upon them, and took them away; yea, they have slain the servants with the edge of the sword; and I only am escaped alone to tell thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said, The fire of God is fallen from heaven, and hath burned up the sheep, and the servants, and consumed them; and I only am escaped alone to tell thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said, The Chaldeans made out three bands, and fell upon the camels, and have carried them away, yea, and slain the servants with the edge of the sword; and I only am escaped alone to tell thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was yet speaking, there came also another, and said, Thy sons and thy daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother’s house:
speaker: Narrator

text: and, behold, there came a great wind from the wilderness, and smote the four corners of the house, and it fell upon the young men, and they are dead; and I only am escaped alone to tell thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job arose, and rent his mantle, and shaved his head, and fell down upon the ground, and worshipped,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and said,
Naked came I out of my mother’s womb,
and naked shall I return thither:
the Lord gave, and the Lord hath taken away;
blessed be the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all this Job sinned not, nor charged God foolishly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Again there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan came also among them to present himself before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said unto Satan, From whence comest thou? And Satan answered the Lord, and said, From going to and fro in the earth, and from walking up and down in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said unto Satan, Hast thou considered my servant Job, that there is none like him in the earth, a perfect and an upright man, one that feareth God, and escheweth evil? and still he holdeth fast his integrity, although thou movedst me against him, to destroy him without cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Satan answered the Lord, and said, Skin for skin, yea, all that a man hath will he give for his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: But put forth thine hand now, and touch his bone and his flesh, and he will curse thee to thy face.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said unto Satan, Behold, he is in thine hand; but save his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: So went Satan forth from the presence of the Lord, and smote Job with sore boils from the sole of his foot unto his crown.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he took him a potsherd to scrape himself withal; and he sat down among the ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then said his wife unto him, Dost thou still retain thine integrity? curse God, and die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said unto her, Thou speakest as one of the foolish women speaketh. What? shall we receive good at the hand of God, and shall we not receive evil? In all this did not Job sin with his lips.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when Job’s three friends heard of all this evil that was come upon him, they came every one from his own place; Eliphaz the Temanite, and Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite: for they had made an appointment together to come to mourn with him and to comfort him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they lifted up their eyes afar off, and knew him not, they lifted up their voice, and wept; and they rent every one his mantle, and sprinkled dust upon their heads toward heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they sat down with him upon the ground seven days and seven nights, and none spake a word unto him: for they saw that his grief was very great.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this opened Job his mouth, and cursed his day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Job spake, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the day perish wherein I was born,
and the night in which it was said,
There is a man child conceived.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Lo, let that night be solitary,
let no joyful voice come therein.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them curse it that curse the day,
who are ready to raise up their mourning.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
because it shut not up the doors of my mother’s womb,
nor hid sorrow from mine eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why died I not from the womb?
why did I not give up the ghost when I came out of the belly?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why did the knees prevent me?
or why the breasts that I should suck?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For now should I have lain still and been quiet,
I should have slept:
then had I been at rest,
speaker: Narrator

text:
with kings and counsellors of the earth,
which built desolate places for themselves;
speaker: Narrator

text:
or with princes that had gold,
who filled their houses with silver:
speaker: Narrator

text:
or as an hidden untimely birth I had not been;
as infants which never saw light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There the wicked cease from troubling;
and there the weary be at rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There the prisoners rest together;
they hear not the voice of the oppressor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The small and great are there;
and the servant is free from his master.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wherefore is light given to him that is in misery,
and life unto the bitter in soul;
speaker: Narrator

text:
which long for death, but it cometh not;
and dig for it more than for hid treasures;
speaker: Narrator

text:
which rejoice exceedingly, and are glad,
when they can find the grave?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why is light given to a man whose way is hid,
and whom God hath hedged in?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For my sighing cometh before I eat,
and my roarings are poured out like the waters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the thing which I greatly feared is come upon me,
and that which I was afraid of is come unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was not in safety, neither had I rest,
neither was I quiet; yet trouble came.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
If we assay to commune with thee, wilt thou be grieved?
but who can withhold himself from speaking?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, thou hast instructed many,
and thou hast strengthened the weak hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy words have upholden him that was falling,
and thou hast strengthened the feeble knees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now it is come upon thee, and thou faintest;
it toucheth thee, and thou art troubled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is not this thy fear, thy confidence,
thy hope, and the uprightness of thy ways?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember, I pray thee, who ever perished, being innocent?
or where were the righteous cut off?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even as I have seen, they that plow iniquity,
and sow wickedness, reap the same.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the blast of God they perish,
and by the breath of his nostrils are they consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The roaring of the lion, and the voice of the fierce lion,
and the teeth of the young lions, are broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The old lion perisheth for lack of prey,
and the stout lion’s whelps are scattered abroad.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now a thing was secretly brought to me,
and mine ear received a little thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In thoughts from the visions of the night,
when deep sleep falleth on men,
speaker: Narrator

text:
fear came upon me, and trembling,
which made all my bones to shake.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then a spirit passed before my face;
the hair of my flesh stood up:
speaker: Narrator

text:
it stood still, but I could not discern the form thereof:
an image was before mine eyes, there was silence,
and I heard a voice, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall mortal man be more just than God?
shall a man be more pure than his maker?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, he put no trust in his servants;
and his angels he charged with folly:
speaker: Narrator

text:
how much less in them that dwell in houses of clay,
whose foundation is in the dust,
which are crushed before the moth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are destroyed from morning to evening:
they perish for ever without any regarding it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Doth not their excellency which is in them go away?
they die, even without wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Call now, if there be any that will answer thee;
and to which of the saints wilt thou turn?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For wrath killeth the foolish man,
and envy slayeth the silly one.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have seen the foolish taking root:
but suddenly I cursed his habitation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His children are far from safety,
and they are crushed in the gate,
neither is there any to deliver them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whose harvest the hungry eateth up,
and taketh it even out of the thorns,
and the robber swalloweth up their substance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Although affliction cometh not forth of the dust,
neither doth trouble spring out of the ground;
speaker: Narrator

text:
yet man is born unto trouble,
as the sparks fly upward.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would seek unto God,
and unto God would I commit my cause:
speaker: Narrator

text:
which doeth great things and unsearchable;
marvellous things without number:
speaker: Narrator

text:
who giveth rain upon the earth,
and sendeth waters upon the fields:
speaker: Narrator

text:
to set up on high those that be low;
that those which mourn may be exalted to safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He disappointeth the devices of the crafty,
so that their hands cannot perform their enterprise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He taketh the wise in their own craftiness:
and the counsel of the froward is carried headlong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They meet with darkness in the daytime,
and grope in the noonday as in the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he saveth the poor from the sword,
from their mouth, and from the hand of the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the poor hath hope,
and iniquity stoppeth her mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, happy is the man whom God correcteth:
therefore despise not thou the chastening of the Almighty:
speaker: Narrator

text:
for he maketh sore, and bindeth up:
he woundeth, and his hands make whole.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall deliver thee in six troubles:
yea, in seven there shall no evil touch thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In famine he shall redeem thee from death:
and in war from the power of the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou shalt be hid from the scourge of the tongue:
neither shalt thou be afraid of destruction when it cometh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At destruction and famine thou shalt laugh:
neither shalt thou be afraid of the beasts of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For thou shalt be in league with the stones of the field:
and the beasts of the field shall be at peace with thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And thou shalt know that thy tabernacle shall be in peace;
and thou shalt visit thy habitation, and shalt not sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou shalt know also that thy seed shall be great,
and thine offspring as the grass of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou shalt come to thy grave in a full age,
like as a shock of corn cometh in in his season.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lo this, we have searched it, so it is;
hear it, and know thou it for thy good.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Job answered and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh that my grief were throughly weighed,
and my calamity laid in the balances together!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For now it would be heavier than the sand of the sea:
therefore my words are swallowed up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the arrows of the Almighty are within me,
the poison whereof drinketh up my spirit:
the terrors of God do set themselves in array against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Doth the wild ass bray when he hath grass?
or loweth the ox over his fodder?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can that which is unsavoury be eaten without salt?
or is there any taste in the white of an egg?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The things that my soul refused to touch
are as my sorrowful meat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh that I might have my request;
and that God would grant me the thing that I long for!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even that it would please God to destroy me;
that he would let loose his hand, and cut me off!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
What is my strength, that I should hope?
and what is mine end, that I should prolong my life?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is my strength the strength of stones?
or is my flesh of brass?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is not my help in me?
and is wisdom driven quite from me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
To him that is afflicted pity should be shewed from his friend;
but he forsaketh the fear of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My brethren have dealt deceitfully as a brook,
and as the stream of brooks they pass away;
speaker: Narrator

text:
which are blackish by reason of the ice,
and wherein the snow is hid:
speaker: Narrator

text:
what time they wax warm, they vanish:
when it is hot, they are consumed out of their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The paths of their way are turned aside;
they go to nothing, and perish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The troops of Tema looked,
the companies of Sheba waited for them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were confounded because they had hoped;
they came thither, and were ashamed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For now ye are nothing;
ye see my casting down, and are afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did I say, Bring unto me?
or, Give a reward for me of your substance?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or, Deliver me from the enemy’s hand?
or, Redeem me from the hand of the mighty?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Teach me, and I will hold my tongue:
and cause me to understand wherein I have erred.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How forcible are right words!
but what doth your arguing reprove?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do ye imagine to reprove words,
and the speeches of one that is desperate, which are as wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yea, ye overwhelm the fatherless,
and ye dig a pit for your friend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now therefore be content, look upon me;
for it is evident unto you if I lie.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Return, I pray you, let it not be iniquity;
yea, return again, my righteousness is in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is there iniquity in my tongue?
cannot my taste discern perverse things?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is there not an appointed time to man upon earth?
are not his days also like the days of an hireling?
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a servant earnestly desireth the shadow,
and as an hireling looketh for the reward of his work:
speaker: Narrator

text:
so am I made to possess months of vanity,
and wearisome nights are appointed to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I lie down, I say, When shall I arise, and the night be gone?
and I am full of tossings to and fro unto the dawning of the day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My flesh is clothed with worms and clods of dust;
my skin is broken, and become loathsome.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle,
and are spent without hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O remember that my life is wind:
mine eye shall no more see good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eye of him that hath seen me shall see me no more:
thine eyes are upon me, and I am not.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the cloud is consumed and vanisheth away:
so he that goeth down to the grave shall come up no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall return no more to his house,
neither shall his place know him any more.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Am I a sea, or a whale, that thou settest a watch over me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I say, My bed shall comfort me,
my couch shall ease my complaint;
speaker: Narrator

text:
then thou scarest me with dreams,
and terrifiest me through visions:
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that my soul chooseth strangling,
and death rather than my life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I loathe it; I would not live alway:
let me alone; for my days are vanity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What is man, that thou shouldest magnify him?
and that thou shouldest set thine heart upon him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
And that thou shouldest visit him every morning,
and try him every moment?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How long wilt thou not depart from me,
nor let me alone till I swallow down my spittle?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have sinned; what shall I do unto thee,
O thou preserver of men?
why hast thou set me as a mark against thee,
so that I am a burden to myself?
speaker: Narrator

text:
And why dost thou not pardon my transgression,
and take away mine iniquity?
for now shall I sleep in the dust;
and thou shalt seek me in the morning,
but I shall not be.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
How long wilt thou speak these things?
and how long shall the words of thy mouth be like a strong wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Doth God pervert judgment?
or doth the Almighty pervert justice?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If thy children have sinned against him,
and he have cast them away for their transgression;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if thou wouldest seek unto God betimes,
and make thy supplication to the Almighty;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Though thy beginning was small,
yet thy latter end should greatly increase.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For enquire, I pray thee, of the former age,
and prepare thyself to the search of their fathers:
speaker: Narrator

text:
(for we are but of yesterday, and know nothing,
because our days upon earth are a shadow:)
speaker: Narrator

text:
shall not they teach thee, and tell thee,
and utter words out of their heart?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can the rush grow up without mire?
can the flag grow without water?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whilst it is yet in his greenness, and not cut down,
it withereth before any other herb.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So are the paths of all that forget God;
and the hypocrite’s hope shall perish:
speaker: Narrator

text:
whose hope shall be cut off,
and whose trust shall be a spider’s web.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall lean upon his house, but it shall not stand:
he shall hold it fast, but it shall not endure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is green before the sun,
and his branch shooteth forth in his garden.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His roots are wrapped about the heap,
and seeth the place of stones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If he destroy him from his place,
then it shall deny him,
saying, I have not seen thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, this is the joy of his way,
and out of the earth shall others grow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, God will not cast away a perfect man,
neither will he help the evil doers:
speaker: Narrator

text:
till he fill thy mouth with laughing,
and thy lips with rejoicing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They that hate thee shall be clothed with shame;
and the dwelling place of the wicked shall come to nought.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I know it is so of a truth:
but how should man be just with God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If he will contend with him,
he cannot answer him one of a thousand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is wise in heart, and mighty in strength:
who hath hardened himself against him, and hath prospered?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which removeth the mountains, and they know not:
which overturneth them in his anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which shaketh the earth out of her place,
and the pillars thereof tremble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which commandeth the sun, and it riseth not;
and sealeth up the stars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which alone spreadeth out the heavens,
and treadeth upon the waves of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which maketh Arcturus, Orion, and Pleiades,
and the chambers of the south.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which doeth great things past finding out;
yea, and wonders without number.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lo, he goeth by me, and I see him not:
he passeth on also, but I perceive him not.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, he taketh away, who can hinder him?
who will say unto him, What doest thou?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If God will not withdraw his anger,
the proud helpers do stoop under him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How much less shall I answer him,
and choose out my words to reason with him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whom, though I were righteous, yet would I not answer,
but I would make supplication to my judge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I had called, and he had answered me;
yet would I not believe that he had hearkened unto my voice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he breaketh me with a tempest,
and multiplieth my wounds without cause.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will not suffer me to take my breath,
but filleth me with bitterness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I speak of strength, lo, he is strong:
and if of judgment, who shall set me a time to plead?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I justify myself, mine own mouth shall condemn me:
if I say, I am perfect, it shall also prove me perverse.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though I were perfect, yet would I not know my soul:
I would despise my life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is one thing, therefore I said it,
He destroyeth the perfect and the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the scourge slay suddenly,
he will laugh at the trial of the innocent.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Now my days are swifter than a post:
they flee away, they see no good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are passed away as the swift ships:
as the eagle that hasteth to the prey.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I say, I will forget my complaint,
I will leave off my heaviness, and comfort myself:
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am afraid of all my sorrows,
I know that thou wilt not hold me innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text: If I be wicked, why then labour I in vain?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I wash myself with snow water,
and make my hands never so clean;
speaker: Narrator

text:
yet shalt thou plunge me in the ditch,
and mine own clothes shall abhor me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he is not a man, as I am, that I should answer him,
and we should come together in judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Neither is there any daysman betwixt us,
that might lay his hand upon us both.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let him take his rod away from me,
and let not his fear terrify me:
speaker: Narrator

text:
then would I speak, and not fear him;
but it is not so with me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will say unto God, Do not condemn me;
shew me wherefore thou contendest with me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it good unto thee that thou shouldest oppress,
that thou shouldest despise the work of thine hands,
and shine upon the counsel of the wicked?
