text: Then answered Zophar the Naamathite, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore do my thoughts cause me to answer,
and for this I make haste.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have heard the check of my reproach,
and the spirit of my understanding causeth me to answer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Knowest thou not this of old,
since man was placed upon earth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that the triumphing of the wicked is short,
and the joy of the hypocrite but for a moment?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though his excellency mount up to the heavens,
and his head reach unto the clouds;
speaker: Narrator

text:
yet he shall perish for ever like his own dung:
they which have seen him shall say, Where is he?
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall fly away as a dream, and shall not be found:
yea, he shall be chased away as a vision of the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eye also which saw him shall see him no more;
neither shall his place any more behold him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His children shall seek to please the poor,
and his hands shall restore their goods.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His bones are full of the sin of his youth,
which shall lie down with him in the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though wickedness be sweet in his mouth,
though he hide it under his tongue;
speaker: Narrator

text:
though he spare it, and forsake it not;
but keep it still within his mouth:
speaker: Narrator

text:
yet his meat in his bowels is turned,
it is the gall of asps within him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath swallowed down riches,
and he shall vomit them up again:
God shall cast them out of his belly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall suck the poison of asps:
the viper’s tongue shall slay him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall not see the rivers, the floods,
the brooks of honey and butter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That which he laboured for shall he restore,
and shall not swallow it down:
according to his substance shall the restitution be,
and he shall not rejoice therein.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because he hath oppressed and hath forsaken the poor;
because he hath violently taken away an house which he builded not;
speaker: Narrator

text:
surely he shall not feel quietness in his belly,
he shall not save of that which he desired.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There shall none of his meat be left;
therefore shall no man look for his goods.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the fulness of his sufficiency he shall be in straits:
every hand of the wicked shall come upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he is about to fill his belly,
God shall cast the fury of his wrath upon him,
and shall rain it upon him while he is eating.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall flee from the iron weapon,
and the bow of steel shall strike him through.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
The heaven shall reveal his iniquity;
and the earth shall rise up against him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The increase of his house shall depart,
and his goods shall flow away in the day of his wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the portion of a wicked man from God,
and the heritage appointed unto him by God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Job answered and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear diligently my speech,
and let this be your consolations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Suffer me that I may speak;
and after that I have spoken, mock on.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for me, is my complaint to man?
and if it were so, why should not my spirit be troubled?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mark me, and be astonished,
and lay your hand upon your mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even when I remember I am afraid,
and trembling taketh hold on my flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wherefore do the wicked live, become old,
yea, are mighty in power?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their seed is established in their sight with them,
and their offspring before their eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their houses are safe from fear,
neither is the rod of God upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their bull gendereth, and faileth not;
their cow calveth, and casteth not her calf.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They send forth their little ones like a flock,
and their children dance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They take the timbrel and harp,
and rejoice at the sound of the organ.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They spend their days in wealth,
and in a moment go down to the grave.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore they say unto God, Depart from us;
for we desire not the knowledge of thy ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What is the Almighty, that we should serve him?
and what profit should we have, if we pray unto him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lo, their good is not in their hand:
the counsel of the wicked is far from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How oft is the candle of the wicked put out!
and how oft cometh their destruction upon them!
God distributeth sorrows in his anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are as stubble before the wind,
and as chaff that the storm carrieth away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God layeth up his iniquity for his children:
he rewardeth him, and he shall know it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His eyes shall see his destruction,
and he shall drink of the wrath of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For what pleasure hath he in his house after him,
when the number of his months is cut off in the midst?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall any teach God knowledge?
seeing he judgeth those that are high.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One dieth in his full strength,
being wholly at ease and quiet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His breasts are full of milk,
and his bones are moistened with marrow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And another dieth in the bitterness of his soul,
and never eateth with pleasure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They shall lie down alike in the dust,
and the worms shall cover them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, I know your thoughts,
and the devices which ye wrongfully imagine against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For ye say, Where is the house of the prince?
and where are the dwelling places of the wicked?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have ye not asked them that go by the way?
and do ye not know their tokens,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that the wicked is reserved to the day of destruction?
they shall be brought forth to the day of wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who shall declare his way to his face?
and who shall repay him what he hath done?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet shall he be brought to the grave,
and shall remain in the tomb.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The clods of the valley shall be sweet unto him,
and every man shall draw after him,
as there are innumerable before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How then comfort ye me in vain,
seeing in your answers there remaineth falsehood?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can a man be profitable unto God,
as he that is wise may be profitable unto himself?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it any pleasure to the Almighty, that thou art righteous?
or is it gain to him, that thou makest thy ways perfect?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he reprove thee for fear of thee?
will he enter with thee into judgment?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is not thy wickedness great?
and thine iniquities infinite?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For thou hast taken a pledge from thy brother for nought,
and stripped the naked of their clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou hast not given water to the weary to drink,
and thou hast withholden bread from the hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But as for the mighty man, he had the earth;
and the honourable man dwelt in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou hast sent widows away empty,
and the arms of the fatherless have been broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore snares are round about thee,
and sudden fear troubleth thee;
speaker: Narrator

text:
or darkness, that thou canst not see;
and abundance of waters cover thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is not God in the height of heaven?
and behold the height of the stars, how high they are!
speaker: Narrator

text:
And thou sayest, How doth God know?
can he judge through the dark cloud?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thick clouds are a covering to him, that he seeth not;
and he walketh in the circuit of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hast thou marked the old way which wicked men have trodden?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which were cut down out of time,
whose foundation was overflown with a flood:
speaker: Narrator

text:
which said unto God, Depart from us:
and what can the Almighty do for them?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet he filled their houses with good things:
but the counsel of the wicked is far from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous see it, and are glad:
and the innocent laugh them to scorn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whereas our substance is not cut down,
but the remnant of them the fire consumeth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Acquaint now thyself with him, and be at peace:
thereby good shall come unto thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Receive, I pray thee, the law from his mouth,
and lay up his words in thine heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If thou return to the Almighty, thou shalt be built up,
thou shalt put away iniquity far from thy tabernacles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then shalt thou lay up gold as dust,
and the gold of Ophir as the stones of the brooks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yea, the Almighty shall be thy defence,
and thou shalt have plenty of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For then shalt thou have thy delight in the Almighty,
and shalt lift up thy face unto God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou shalt make thy prayer unto him, and he shall hear thee,
and thou shalt pay thy vows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou shalt also decree a thing,
and it shall be established unto thee:
and the light shall shine upon thy ways.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He shall deliver the island of the innocent:
and it is delivered by the pureness of thine hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even to day is my complaint bitter:
my stroke is heavier than my groaning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh that I knew where I might find him!
that I might come even to his seat!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would order my cause before him,
and fill my mouth with arguments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would know the words which he would answer me,
and understand what he would say unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he plead against me with his great power?
No; but he would put strength in me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There the righteous might dispute with him;
so should I be delivered for ever from my judge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, I go forward, but he is not there;
and backward, but I cannot perceive him:
speaker: Narrator

text:
on the left hand, where he doth work, but I cannot behold him:
he hideth himself on the right hand, that I cannot see him:
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he knoweth the way that I take:
when he hath tried me, I shall come forth as gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My foot hath held his steps,
his way have I kept, and not declined.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Neither have I gone back from the commandment of his lips;
I have esteemed the words of his mouth more than my necessary food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he is in one mind, and who can turn him?
and what his soul desireth, even that he doeth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he performeth the thing that is appointed for me:
and many such things are with him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore am I troubled at his presence:
when I consider, I am afraid of him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God maketh my heart soft,
and the Almighty troubleth me:
speaker: Narrator

text:
because I was not cut off before the darkness,
neither hath he covered the darkness from my face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why, seeing times are not hidden from the Almighty,
do they that know him not see his days?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some remove the landmarks;
they violently take away flocks, and feed thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They drive away the ass of the fatherless,
they take the widow’s ox for a pledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They turn the needy out of the way:
the poor of the earth hide themselves together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, as wild asses in the desert, go they forth to their work; rising betimes for a prey:
the wilderness yieldeth food for them and for their children.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They reap every one his corn in the field:
and they gather the vintage of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They cause the naked to lodge without clothing,
that they have no covering in the cold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are wet with the showers of the mountains,
and embrace the rock for want of a shelter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They pluck the fatherless from the breast,
and take a pledge of the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They cause him to go naked without clothing,
and they take away the sheaf from the hungry;
speaker: Narrator

text:
which make oil within their walls,
and tread their winepresses, and suffer thirst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Men groan from out of the city,
and the soul of the wounded crieth out:
yet God layeth not folly to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are of those that rebel against the light;
they know not the ways thereof, nor abide in the paths thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The murderer rising with the light killeth the poor and needy,
and in the night is as a thief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eye also of the adulterer waiteth for the twilight,
saying, No eye shall see me: and disguiseth his face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the dark they dig through houses,
which they had marked for themselves in the daytime:
they know not the light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the morning is to them even as the shadow of death:
if one know them, they are in the terrors of the shadow of death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is swift as the waters; their portion is cursed in the earth:
he beholdeth not the way of the vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Drought and heat consume the snow waters:
so doth the grave those which have sinned.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He evil entreateth the barren that beareth not:
and doeth not good to the widow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He draweth also the mighty with his power:
he riseth up, and no man is sure of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though it be given him to be in safety, whereon he resteth;
yet his eyes are upon their ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are exalted for a little while,
but are gone and brought low;
they are taken out of the way as all other,
and cut off as the tops of the ears of corn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And if it be not so now, who will make me a liar,
and make my speech nothing worth?
speaker: Narrator

text: Then answered Bildad the Shuhite, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Dominion and fear are with him,
he maketh peace in his high places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is there any number of his armies?
and upon whom doth not his light arise?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How then can man be justified with God?
or how can he be clean that is born of a woman?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold even to the moon, and it shineth not;
yea, the stars are not pure in his sight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How much less man, that is a worm?
and the son of man, which is a worm?
speaker: Narrator

text: But Job answered and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
How hast thou helped him that is without power?
how savest thou the arm that hath no strength?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How hast thou counselled him that hath no wisdom?
and how hast thou plentifully declared the thing as it is?
speaker: Narrator

text:
To whom hast thou uttered words?
and whose spirit came from thee?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Dead things are formed from under the waters,
and the inhabitants thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hell is naked before him,
and destruction hath no covering.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He stretcheth out the north over the empty place,
and hangeth the earth upon nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He bindeth up the waters in his thick clouds;
and the cloud is not rent under them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He holdeth back the face of his throne,
and spreadeth his cloud upon it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath compassed the waters with bounds,
until the day and night come to an end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pillars of heaven tremble
and are astonished at his reproof.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He divideth the sea with his power,
and by his understanding he smiteth through the proud.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By his spirit he hath garnished the heavens;
his hand hath formed the crooked serpent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lo, these are parts of his ways:
but how little a portion is heard of him?
but the thunder of his power who can understand?
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover Job continued his parable, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
As God liveth, who hath taken away my judgment;
and the Almighty, who hath vexed my soul;
speaker: Narrator

text:
all the while my breath is in me,
and the spirit of God is in my nostrils;
speaker: Narrator

text:
my lips shall not speak wickedness,
nor my tongue utter deceit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God forbid that I should justify you:
till I die I will not remove mine integrity from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My righteousness I hold fast, and will not let it go:
my heart shall not reproach me so long as I live.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let mine enemy be as the wicked,
and he that riseth up against me as the unrighteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For what is the hope of the hypocrite, though he hath gained,
when God taketh away his soul?
speaker: Narrator

text: Will God hear his cry when trouble cometh upon him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he delight himself in the Almighty?
will he always call upon God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will teach you by the hand of God:
that which is with the Almighty will I not conceal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, all ye yourselves have seen it;
why then are ye thus altogether vain?
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the portion of a wicked man with God,
and the heritage of oppressors, which they shall receive of the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If his children be multiplied, it is for the sword:
and his offspring shall not be satisfied with bread.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those that remain of him shall be buried in death:
and his widows shall not weep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though he heap up silver as the dust,
and prepare raiment as the clay;
speaker: Narrator

text:
he may prepare it, but the just shall put it on,
and the innocent shall divide the silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He buildeth his house as a moth,
and as a booth that the keeper maketh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rich man shall lie down, but he shall not be gathered:
he openeth his eyes, and he is not.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terrors take hold on him as waters,
a tempest stealeth him away in the night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The east wind carrieth him away, and he departeth:
and as a storm hurleth him out of his place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God shall cast upon him, and not spare:
he would fain flee out of his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Men shall clap their hands at him,
and shall hiss him out of his place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely there is a vein for the silver,
and a place for gold where they fine it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Iron is taken out of the earth,
and brass is molten out of the stone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He setteth an end to darkness,
and searcheth out all perfection:
the stones of darkness, and the shadow of death.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
As for the earth, out of it cometh bread:
and under it is turned up as it were fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The stones of it are the place of sapphires:
and it hath dust of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is a path which no fowl knoweth,
and which the vulture’s eye hath not seen:
speaker: Narrator

text:
the lion’s whelps have not trodden it,
nor the fierce lion passed by it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He putteth forth his hand upon the rock;
he overturneth the mountains by the roots.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He cutteth out rivers among the rocks;
and his eye seeth every precious thing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He bindeth the floods from overflowing;
and the thing that is hid bringeth he forth to light.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But where shall wisdom be found?
and where is the place of understanding?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Man knoweth not the price thereof;
neither is it found in the land of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The depth saith, It is not in me:
and the sea saith, It is not with me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It cannot be gotten for gold,
neither shall silver be weighed for the price thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It cannot be valued with the gold of Ophir,
with the precious onyx, or the sapphire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The gold and the crystal cannot equal it:
and the exchange of it shall not be for jewels of fine gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No mention shall be made of coral, or of pearls:
for the price of wisdom is above rubies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The topaz of Ethiopia shall not equal it,
neither shall it be valued with pure gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whence then cometh wisdom?
and where is the place of understanding?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Seeing it is hid from the eyes of all living,
and kept close from the fowls of the air.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Destruction and death say,
We have heard the fame thereof with our ears.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God understandeth the way thereof,
and he knoweth the place thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he looketh to the ends of the earth,
and seeth under the whole heaven;
speaker: Narrator

text:
to make the weight for the winds;
and he weigheth the waters by measure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he made a decree for the rain,
and a way for the lightning of the thunder:
speaker: Narrator

text:
then did he see it, and declare it;
he prepared it, yea, and searched it out.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: Moreover Job continued his parable, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh that I were as in months past,
as in the days when God preserved me;
speaker: Narrator

text:
when his candle shined upon my head,
and when by his light I walked through darkness;
speaker: Narrator

text:
as I was in the days of my youth,
when the secret of God was upon my tabernacle;
speaker: Narrator

text:
when the Almighty was yet with me,
when my children were about me;
speaker: Narrator

text:
when I washed my steps with butter,
and the rock poured me out rivers of oil;
speaker: Narrator

text:
when I went out to the gate through the city,
when I prepared my seat in the street!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The young men saw me, and hid themselves:
and the aged arose, and stood up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The princes refrained talking,
and laid their hand on their mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The nobles held their peace,
and their tongue cleaved to the roof of their mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the ear heard me, then it blessed me;
and when the eye saw me, it gave witness to me:
speaker: Narrator

text:
because I delivered the poor that cried, and the fatherless,
and him that had none to help him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The blessing of him that was ready to perish came upon me:
and I caused the widow’s heart to sing for joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I put on righteousness, and it clothed me:
my judgment was as a robe and a diadem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was eyes to the blind,
and feet was I to the lame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was a father to the poor:
and the cause which I knew not I searched out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And I brake the jaws of the wicked,
and plucked the spoil out of his teeth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I said, I shall die in my nest,
and I shall multiply my days as the sand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My root was spread out by the waters,
and the dew lay all night upon my branch.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My glory was fresh in me,
and my bow was renewed in my hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Unto me men gave ear, and waited,
and kept silence at my counsel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
After my words they spake not again;
and my speech dropped upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And they waited for me as for the rain;
and they opened their mouth wide as for the latter rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I laughed on them, they believed it not;
and the light of my countenance they cast not down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I chose out their way, and sat chief,
and dwelt as a king in the army,
as one that comforteth the mourners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now they that are younger than I have me in derision,
whose fathers I would have disdained to have set with the dogs of my flock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yea, whereto might the strength of their hands profit me,
in whom old age was perished?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For want and famine they were solitary;
fleeing into the wilderness in former time desolate and waste.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who cut up mallows by the bushes,
and juniper roots for their meat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were driven forth from among men,
(they cried after them as after a thief;)
speaker: Narrator

text:
to dwell in the clifts of the valleys,
in caves of the earth, and in the rocks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Among the bushes they brayed;
under the nettles they were gathered together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were children of fools, yea, children of base men:
they were viler than the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And now am I their song,
yea, I am their byword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They abhor me, they flee far from me,
and spare not to spit in my face.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because he hath loosed my cord, and afflicted me,
they have also let loose the bridle before me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They mar my path,
they set forward my calamity,
they have no helper.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They came upon me as a wide breaking in of waters:
in the desolation they rolled themselves upon me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Terrors are turned upon me:
they pursue my soul as the wind:
and my welfare passeth away as a cloud.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And now my soul is poured out upon me;
the days of affliction have taken hold upon me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My bones are pierced in me in the night season:
and my sinews take no rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the great force of my disease is my garment changed:
it bindeth me about as the collar of my coat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He hath cast me into the mire,
and I am become like dust and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I cry unto thee, and thou dost not hear me:
I stand up, and thou regardest me not.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou art become cruel to me:
with thy strong hand thou opposest thyself against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thou liftest me up to the wind;
thou causest me to ride upon it, and dissolvest my substance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I know that thou wilt bring me to death,
and to the house appointed for all living.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Howbeit he will not stretch out his hand to the grave,
though they cry in his destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did not I weep for him that was in trouble?
was not my soul grieved for the poor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I looked for good, then evil came unto me:
and when I waited for light, there came darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My bowels boiled, and rested not:
the days of affliction prevented me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I went mourning without the sun:
I stood up, and I cried in the congregation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am a brother to dragons,
and a companion to owls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My skin is black upon me,
and my bones are burned with heat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My harp also is turned to mourning,
and my organ into the voice of them that weep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I made a covenant with mine eyes;
why then should I think upon a maid?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For what portion of God is there from above?
and what inheritance of the Almighty from on high?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is not destruction to the wicked?
and a strange punishment to the workers of iniquity?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Doth not he see my ways,
and count all my steps?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have walked with vanity,
or if my foot hath hasted to deceit;
speaker: Narrator

text:
let me be weighed in an even balance,
that God may know mine integrity.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
then let me sow, and let another eat;
yea, let my offspring be rooted out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If mine heart have been deceived by a woman,
or if I have laid wait at my neighbour’s door;
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let my wife grind unto another,
and let others bow down upon her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For this is an heinous crime;
yea, it is an iniquity to be punished by the judges.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For it is a fire that consumeth to destruction,
and would root out all mine increase.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I did despise the cause of my manservant or of my maidservant,
when they contended with me;
speaker: Narrator

text:
what then shall I do when God riseth up?
and when he visiteth, what shall I answer him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Did not he that made me in the womb make him?
and did not one fashion us in the womb?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have withheld the poor from their desire,
or have caused the eyes of the widow to fail;
speaker: Narrator

text:
or have eaten my morsel myself alone,
and the fatherless hath not eaten thereof;
speaker: Narrator

text:
(for from my youth he was brought up with me, as with a father,
and I have guided her from my mother’s womb;)
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have seen any perish for want of clothing,
or any poor without covering;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if his loins have not blessed me,
and if he were not warmed with the fleece of my sheep;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have lifted up my hand against the fatherless,
when I saw my help in the gate:
speaker: Narrator

text:
then let mine arm fall from my shoulder blade,
and mine arm be broken from the bone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For destruction from God was a terror to me,
and by reason of his highness I could not endure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I have made gold my hope,
or have said to the fine gold, Thou art my confidence;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I rejoiced because my wealth was great,
and because mine hand had gotten much;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I beheld the sun when it shined,
or the moon walking in brightness;
speaker: Narrator

text:
and my heart hath been secretly enticed,
or my mouth hath kissed my hand:
speaker: Narrator

text:
this also were an iniquity to be punished by the judge:
for I should have denied the God that is above.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I rejoiced at the destruction of him that hated me,
or lifted up myself when evil found him:
speaker: Narrator

text:
neither have I suffered my mouth to sin
by wishing a curse to his soul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the men of my tabernacle said not,
Oh that we had of his flesh! we cannot be satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The stranger did not lodge in the street:
but I opened my doors to the traveller.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I covered my transgressions as Adam,
by hiding mine iniquity in my bosom:
speaker: Narrator

text:
did I fear a great multitude,
or did the contempt of families terrify me,
that I kept silence, and went not out of the door?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oh that one would hear me!
behold, my desire is, that the Almighty would answer me,
and that mine adversary had written a book.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely I would take it upon my shoulder,
and bind it as a crown to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I would declare unto him the number of my steps;
as a prince would I go near unto him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If my land cry against me,
or that the furrows likewise thereof complain;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if I have eaten the fruits thereof without money,
or have caused the owners thereof to lose their life:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: So these three men ceased to answer Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then was kindled the wrath of Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite, of the kindred of Ram: against Job was his wrath kindled, because he justified himself rather than God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also against his three friends was his wrath kindled, because they had found no answer, and yet had condemned Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Elihu had waited till Job had spoken, because they were elder than he.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Elihu saw that there was no answer in the mouth of these three men, then his wrath was kindled.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I said, Days should speak,
and multitude of years should teach wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But there is a spirit in man:
and the inspiration of the Almighty giveth them understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Great men are not always wise:
neither do the aged understand judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore I said, Hearken to me;
I also will shew mine opinion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, I waited for your words;
I gave ear to your reasons, whilst ye searched out what to say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yea, I attended unto you,
and, behold, there was none of you that convinced Job,
or that answered his words:
speaker: Narrator

text:
lest ye should say, We have found out wisdom:
God thrusteth him down, not man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now he hath not directed his words against me:
neither will I answer him with your speeches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were amazed, they answered no more:
they left off speaking.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I had waited, (for they spake not,
but stood still, and answered no more;)
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, I will answer also my part,
I also will shew mine opinion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I am full of matter,
the spirit within me constraineth me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, my belly is as wine which hath no vent;
it is ready to burst like new bottles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will speak, that I may be refreshed:
I will open my lips and answer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let me not, I pray you, accept any man’s person,
neither let me give flattering titles unto man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I know not to give flattering titles;
in so doing my maker would soon take me away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wherefore, Job, I pray thee, hear my speeches,
and hearken to all my words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, now I have opened my mouth,
my tongue hath spoken in my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My words shall be of the uprightness of my heart:
and my lips shall utter knowledge clearly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Spirit of God hath made me,
and the breath of the Almighty hath given me life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If thou canst answer me,
set thy words in order before me, stand up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, I am according to thy wish in God’s stead:
I also am formed out of the clay.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, my terror shall not make thee afraid,
neither shall my hand be heavy upon thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely thou hast spoken in mine hearing,
and I have heard the voice of thy words, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am clean without transgression, I am innocent;
neither is there iniquity in me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, he findeth occasions against me,
he counteth me for his enemy,
speaker: Narrator

text:
he putteth my feet in the stocks,
he marketh all my paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, in this thou art not just:
I will answer thee, that God is greater than man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why dost thou strive against him?
for he giveth not account of any of his matters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God speaketh once, yea twice,
yet man perceiveth it not.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In a dream, in a vision of the night,
when deep sleep falleth upon men, in slumberings upon the bed;
speaker: Narrator

text:
then he openeth the ears of men,
and sealeth their instruction,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that he may withdraw man from his purpose,
and hide pride from man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He keepeth back his soul from the pit,
and his life from perishing by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is chastened also with pain upon his bed,
and the multitude of his bones with strong pain:
speaker: Narrator

text:
So that his life abhorreth bread,
and his soul dainty meat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His flesh is consumed away, that it cannot be seen;
and his bones that were not seen stick out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yea, his soul draweth near unto the grave,
and his life to the destroyers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If there be a messenger with him, an interpreter,
one among a thousand, to shew unto man his uprightness:
speaker: Narrator

text:
then he is gracious unto him, and saith,
Deliver him from going down to the pit: I have found a ransom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His flesh shall be fresher than a child’s:
he shall return to the days of his youth:
speaker: Narrator

text:
he shall pray unto God,
and he will be favourable unto him:
and he shall see his face with joy:
for he will render unto man his righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He looketh upon men, and if any say, I have sinned,
and perverted that which was right, and it profited me not;
speaker: Narrator

text:
he will deliver his soul from going into the pit,
and his life shall see the light.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lo, all these things worketh God oftentimes with man,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to bring back his soul from the pit,
to be enlightened with the light of the living.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mark well, O Job, hearken unto me:
hold thy peace, and I will speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If thou hast any thing to say, answer me:
speak, for I desire to justify thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If not, hearken unto me:
hold thy peace, and I shall teach thee wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Furthermore Elihu answered and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear my words, O ye wise men;
and give ear unto me, ye that have knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the ear trieth words, as the mouth tasteth meat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let us choose to us judgment:
let us know among ourselves what is good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For Job hath said, I am righteous:
and God hath taken away my judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should I lie against my right?
my wound is incurable without transgression.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What man is like Job,
who drinketh up scorning like water?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which goeth in company with the workers of iniquity,
and walketh with wicked men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he hath said, It profiteth a man nothing
that he should delight himself with God.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For the work of a man shall he render unto him,
and cause every man to find according to his ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yea, surely God will not do wickedly,
neither will the Almighty pervert judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who hath given him a charge over the earth?
or who hath disposed the whole world?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If he set his heart upon man,
if he gather unto himself his spirit and his breath;
speaker: Narrator

text:
all flesh shall perish together,
and man shall turn again unto dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If now thou hast understanding, hear this:
hearken to the voice of my words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall even he that hateth right govern?
and wilt thou condemn him that is most just?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is it fit to say to a king, Thou art wicked?
and to princes, Ye are ungodly?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How much less to him that accepteth not the persons of princes,
nor regardeth the rich more than the poor?
for they all are the work of his hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In a moment shall they die,
and the people shall be troubled at midnight, and pass away:
and the mighty shall be taken away without hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For his eyes are upon the ways of man,
and he seeth all his goings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is no darkness, nor shadow of death,
where the workers of iniquity may hide themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he will not lay upon man more than right;
that he should enter into judgment with God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He shall break in pieces mighty men without number,
and set others in their stead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore he knoweth their works,
and he overturneth them in the night, so that they are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He striketh them as wicked men in the open sight of others;
speaker: Narrator

text:
because they turned back from him,
and would not consider any of his ways:
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that they cause the cry of the poor to come unto him,
and he heareth the cry of the afflicted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he giveth quietness, who then can make trouble?
and when he hideth his face, who then can behold him?
whether it be done against a nation, or against a man only:
speaker: Narrator

text: that the hypocrite reign not, lest the people be ensnared.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely it is meet to be said unto God,
I have borne chastisement, I will not offend any more:
speaker: Narrator

text:
that which I see not teach thou me:
if I have done iniquity, I will do no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should it be according to thy mind?
he will recompense it, whether thou refuse, or whether thou choose; and not I:
therefore speak what thou knowest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let men of understanding tell me,
and let a wise man hearken unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Job hath spoken without knowledge,
and his words were without wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My desire is that Job may be tried unto the end
because of his answers for wicked men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he addeth rebellion unto his sin,
he clappeth his hands among us,
and multiplieth his words against God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu spake moreover, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thinkest thou this to be right, that thou saidst,
My righteousness is more than God’s?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For thou saidst, What advantage will it be unto thee?
and, What profit shall I have, if I be cleansed from my sin?
speaker: Narrator

text: I will answer thee, and thy companions with thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look unto the heavens, and see;
and behold the clouds which are higher than thou.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If thou sinnest, what doest thou against him?
or if thy transgressions be multiplied, what doest thou unto him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
If thou be righteous, what givest thou him?
or what receiveth he of thine hand?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thy wickedness may hurt a man as thou art;
and thy righteousness may profit the son of man.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By reason of the multitude of oppressions they make the oppressed to cry:
they cry out by reason of the arm of the mighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But none saith, Where is God my maker,
who giveth songs in the night;
speaker: Narrator

text:
who teacheth us more than the beasts of the earth,
and maketh us wiser than the fowls of heaven?
speaker: Narrator

text:
There they cry, but none giveth answer,
because of the pride of evil men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely God will not hear vanity,
neither will the Almighty regard it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Although thou sayest thou shalt not see him,
yet judgment is before him; therefore trust thou in him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But now, because it is not so, he hath visited in his anger;
yet he knoweth it not in great extremity:
speaker: Narrator

text:
therefore doth Job open his mouth in vain;
he multiplieth words without knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elihu also proceeded, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: Suffer me a little, and I will shew thee that I have yet to speak on God’s behalf.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will fetch my knowledge from afar,
and will ascribe righteousness to my Maker.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For truly my words shall not be false:
he that is perfect in knowledge is with thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, God is mighty, and despiseth not any:
he is mighty in strength and wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He preserveth not the life of the wicked:
but giveth right to the poor.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
And if they be bound in fetters,
and be holden in cords of affliction;
speaker: Narrator

text:
then he sheweth them their work,
and their transgressions that they have exceeded.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He openeth also their ear to discipline,
and commandeth that they return from iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If they obey and serve him,
they shall spend their days in prosperity, and their years in pleasures.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But if they obey not,
they shall perish by the sword,
and they shall die without knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the hypocrites in heart heap up wrath:
they cry not when he bindeth them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They die in youth,
and their life is among the unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He delivereth the poor in his affliction,
and openeth their ears in oppression.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
But thou hast fulfilled the judgment of the wicked:
judgment and justice take hold on thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because there is wrath, beware lest he take thee away with his stroke:
then a great ransom cannot deliver thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he esteem thy riches?
no, not gold, nor all the forces of strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Desire not the night,
when people are cut off in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take heed, regard not iniquity:
for this hast thou chosen rather than affliction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, God exalteth by his power:
who teacheth like him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who hath enjoined him his way?
or who can say, Thou hast wrought iniquity?
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember that thou magnify his work, which men behold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every man may see it; man may behold it afar off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, God is great, and we know him not,
neither can the number of his years be searched out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he maketh small the drops of water:
they pour down rain according to the vapour thereof:
speaker: Narrator

text: which the clouds do drop and distil upon man abundantly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Also can any understand the spreadings of the clouds,
or the noise of his tabernacle?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, he spreadeth his light upon it,
and covereth the bottom of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For by them judgeth he the people;
he giveth meat in abundance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With clouds he covereth the light;
and commandeth it not to shine by the cloud that cometh betwixt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The noise thereof sheweth concerning it,
the cattle also concerning the vapour.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At this also my heart trembleth,
and is moved out of his place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear attentively the noise of his voice,
and the sound that goeth out of his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He directeth it under the whole heaven,
and his lightning unto the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
God thundereth marvellously with his voice;
great things doeth he, which we cannot comprehend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he saith to the snow, Be thou on the earth;
likewise to the small rain, and to the great rain of his strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sealeth up the hand of every man;
that all men may know his work.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the beasts go into dens,
and remain in their places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of the south cometh the whirlwind:
and cold out of the north.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the breath of God frost is given:
and the breadth of the waters is straitened.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Also by watering he wearieth the thick cloud:
he scattereth his bright cloud:
speaker: Narrator

text:
and it is turned round about by his counsels:
that they may do whatsoever he commandeth them
upon the face of the world in the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He causeth it to come, whether for correction,
or for his land, or for mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hearken unto this, O Job:
stand still, and consider the wondrous works of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Dost thou know when God disposed them,
and caused the light of his cloud to shine?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Dost thou know the balancings of the clouds,
the wondrous works of him which is perfect in knowledge?
speaker: Narrator

text:
How thy garments are warm,
when he quieteth the earth by the south wind?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hast thou with him spread out the sky, which is strong,
and as a molten looking glass?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Teach us what we shall say unto him;
for we cannot order our speech by reason of darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall it be told him that I speak?
if a man speak, surely he shall be swallowed up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And now men see not the bright light which is in the clouds:
but the wind passeth, and cleanseth them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fair weather cometh out of the north:
with God is terrible majesty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Touching the Almighty, we cannot find him out:
he is excellent in power, and in judgment, and in plenty of justice:
he will not afflict.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Men do therefore fear him:
he respecteth not any that are wise of heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord answered Job out of the whirlwind, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who is this that darkeneth counsel
by words without knowledge?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gird up now thy loins like a man;
for I will demand of thee, and answer thou me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where wast thou when I laid the foundations of the earth?
declare, if thou hast understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who hath laid the measures thereof, if thou knowest?
or who hath stretched the line upon it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whereupon are the foundations thereof fastened?
or who laid the corner stone thereof;
speaker: Narrator

text:
when the morning stars sang together,
and all the sons of God shouted for joy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or who shut up the sea with doors, when it brake forth,
as if it had issued out of the womb?
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I made the cloud the garment thereof,
and thick darkness a swaddlingband for it,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and brake up for it my decreed place,
and set bars and doors,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and said, Hitherto shalt thou come, but no further:
and here shall thy proud waves be stayed?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hast thou commanded the morning since thy days;
and caused the dayspring to know his place;
speaker: Narrator

text:
that it might take hold of the ends of the earth,
that the wicked might be shaken out of it?
speaker: Narrator

text: It is turned as clay to the seal; and they stand as a garment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And from the wicked their light is withholden,
and the high arm shall be broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hast thou entered into the springs of the sea?
or hast thou walked in the search of the depth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have the gates of death been opened unto thee?
or hast thou seen the doors of the shadow of death?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hast thou perceived the breadth of the earth?
declare if thou knowest it all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where is the way where light dwelleth?
and as for darkness, where is the place thereof,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that thou shouldest take it to the bound thereof,
and that thou shouldest know the paths to the house thereof?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Knowest thou it, because thou wast then born?
or because the number of thy days is great?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hast thou entered into the treasures of the snow?
or hast thou seen the treasures of the hail,
speaker: Narrator

text:
which I have reserved against the time of trouble,
against the day of battle and war?
speaker: Narrator

text:
By what way is the light parted,
which scattereth the east wind upon the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who hath divided a watercourse for the overflowing of waters,
or a way for the lightning of thunder;
speaker: Narrator

text:
to cause it to rain on the earth, where no man is;
on the wilderness, wherein there is no man;
speaker: Narrator

text:
to satisfy the desolate and waste ground;
and to cause the bud of the tender herb to spring forth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hath the rain a father?
or who hath begotten the drops of dew?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of whose womb came the ice?
and the hoary frost of heaven, who hath gendered it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The waters are hid as with a stone,
and the face of the deep is frozen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Canst thou bind the sweet influences of Pleiades,
or loose the bands of Orion?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Canst thou bring forth Mazzaroth in his season?
or canst thou guide Arcturus with his sons?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Knowest thou the ordinances of heaven?
canst thou set the dominion thereof in the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Canst thou lift up thy voice to the clouds,
that abundance of waters may cover thee?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Canst thou send lightnings, that they may go,
and say unto thee, Here we are?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who hath put wisdom in the inward parts?
or who hath given understanding to the heart?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can number the clouds in wisdom?
or who can stay the bottles of heaven,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when the dust groweth into hardness,
and the clods cleave fast together?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wilt thou hunt the prey for the lion?
or fill the appetite of the young lions,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when they couch in their dens,
and abide in the covert to lie in wait?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who provideth for the raven his food?
when his young ones cry unto God, they wander for lack of meat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Knowest thou the time when the wild goats of the rock bring forth?
or canst thou mark when the hinds do calve?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Canst thou number the months that they fulfil?
or knowest thou the time when they bring forth?
speaker: Narrator

text:
They bow themselves, they bring forth their young ones,
they cast out their sorrows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their young ones are in good liking, they grow up with corn;
they go forth, and return not unto them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who hath sent out the wild ass free?
or who hath loosed the bands of the wild ass?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whose house I have made the wilderness,
and the barren land his dwellings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He scorneth the multitude of the city,
neither regardeth he the crying of the driver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The range of the mountains is his pasture,
and he searcheth after every green thing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will the unicorn be willing to serve thee,
or abide by thy crib?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Canst thou bind the unicorn with his band in the furrow?
or will he harrow the valleys after thee?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wilt thou trust him, because his strength is great?
or wilt thou leave thy labour to him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wilt thou believe him, that he will bring home thy seed,
and gather it into thy barn?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gavest thou the goodly wings unto the peacocks?
or wings and feathers unto the ostrich?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Which leaveth her eggs in the earth,
and warmeth them in dust,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and forgetteth that the foot may crush them,
or that the wild beast may break them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is hardened against her young ones, as though they were not hers:
her labour is in vain without fear;
speaker: Narrator

text:
because God hath deprived her of wisdom,
neither hath he imparted to her understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What time she lifteth up herself on high,
she scorneth the horse and his rider.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hast thou given the horse strength?
hast thou clothed his neck with thunder?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Canst thou make him afraid as a grasshopper?
the glory of his nostrils is terrible.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He paweth in the valley, and rejoiceth in his strength:
he goeth on to meet the armed men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He mocketh at fear, and is not affrighted;
neither turneth he back from the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The quiver rattleth against him,
the glittering spear and the shield.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He swalloweth the ground with fierceness and rage:
neither believeth he that it is the sound of the trumpet.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Doth the hawk fly by thy wisdom,
and stretch her wings toward the south?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Doth the eagle mount up at thy command,
and make her nest on high?
speaker: Narrator

text:
She dwelleth and abideth on the rock,
upon the crag of the rock, and the strong place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From thence she seeketh the prey,
and her eyes behold afar off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her young ones also suck up blood:
and where the slain are, there is she.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover the Lord answered Job, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall he that contendeth with the Almighty instruct him?
he that reproveth God, let him answer it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered the Lord, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, I am vile; what shall I answer thee?
I will lay mine hand upon my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Once have I spoken; but I will not answer:
yea, twice; but I will proceed no further.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then answered the Lord unto Job out of the whirlwind, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gird up thy loins now like a man:
I will demand of thee, and declare thou unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wilt thou also disannul my judgment?
wilt thou condemn me, that thou mayest be righteous?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hast thou an arm like God?
or canst thou thunder with a voice like him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Deck thyself now with majesty and excellency;
and array thyself with glory and beauty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cast abroad the rage of thy wrath:
and behold every one that is proud, and abase him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look on every one that is proud, and bring him low;
and tread down the wicked in their place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hide them in the dust together;
and bind their faces in secret.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then will I also confess unto thee
that thine own right hand can save thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold now behemoth, which I made with thee;
he eateth grass as an ox.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lo now, his strength is in his loins,
and his force is in the navel of his belly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He moveth his tail like a cedar:
the sinews of his stones are wrapped together.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His bones are as strong pieces of brass;
his bones are like bars of iron.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is the chief of the ways of God:
he that made him can make his sword to approach unto him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely the mountains bring him forth food,
where all the beasts of the field play.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He lieth under the shady trees,
in the covert of the reed, and fens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The shady trees cover him with their shadow;
the willows of the brook compass him about.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, he drinketh up a river, and hasteth not:
he trusteth that he can draw up Jordan into his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He taketh it with his eyes:
his nose pierceth through snares.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Canst thou draw out leviathan with an hook?
or his tongue with a cord which thou lettest down?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Canst thou put an hook into his nose?
or bore his jaw through with a thorn?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he make many supplications unto thee?
will he speak soft words unto thee?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will he make a covenant with thee?
wilt thou take him for a servant for ever?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wilt thou play with him as with a bird?
or wilt thou bind him for thy maidens?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall the companions make a banquet of him?
shall they part him among the merchants?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Canst thou fill his skin with barbed irons?
or his head with fish spears?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lay thine hand upon him,
remember the battle, do no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Behold, the hope of him is in vain:
shall not one be cast down even at the sight of him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
None is so fierce that dare stir him up:
who then is able to stand before me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who hath prevented me, that I should repay him?
whatsoever is under the whole heaven is mine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will not conceal his parts, nor his power,
nor his comely proportion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can discover the face of his garment?
or who can come to him with his double bridle?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can open the doors of his face?
his teeth are terrible round about.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His scales are his pride,
shut up together as with a close seal.
speaker: Narrator

text: One is so near to another, that no air can come between them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are joined one to another,
they stick together, that they cannot be sundered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By his neesings a light doth shine,
and his eyes are like the eyelids of the morning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of his mouth go burning lamps,
and sparks of fire leap out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Out of his nostrils goeth smoke,
as out of a seething pot or caldron.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His breath kindleth coals,
and a flame goeth out of his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In his neck remaineth strength,
and sorrow is turned into joy before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The flakes of his flesh are joined together:
they are firm in themselves; they cannot be moved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His heart is as firm as a stone;
yea, as hard as a piece of the nether millstone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he raiseth up himself, the mighty are afraid:
by reason of breakings they purify themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sword of him that layeth at him cannot hold:
the spear, the dart, nor the habergeon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He esteemeth iron as straw,
and brass as rotten wood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The arrow cannot make him flee:
slingstones are turned with him into stubble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Darts are counted as stubble:
he laugheth at the shaking of a spear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sharp stones are under him:
he spreadeth sharp pointed things upon the mire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He maketh the deep to boil like a pot:
he maketh the sea like a pot of ointment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He maketh a path to shine after him;
one would think the deep to be hoary.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Upon earth there is not his like,
who is made without fear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He beholdeth all high things:
he is a king over all the children of pride.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Job answered the Lord, and said,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I know that thou canst do every thing,
and that no thought can be withholden from thee.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Hear, I beseech thee, and I will speak:
I will demand of thee, and declare thou unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have heard of thee by the hearing of the ear:
but now mine eye seeth thee.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wherefore I abhor myself,
and repent in dust and ashes.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it was so, that after the Lord had spoken these words unto Job, the Lord said to Eliphaz the Temanite, My wrath is kindled against thee, and against thy two friends: for ye have not spoken of me the thing that is right, as my servant Job hath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore take unto you now seven bullocks and seven rams, and go to my servant Job, and offer up for yourselves a burnt offering; and my servant Job shall pray for you: for him will I accept: lest I deal with you after your folly, in that ye have not spoken of me the thing which is right, like my servant Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Eliphaz the Temanite and Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite went, and did according as the Lord commanded them: the Lord also accepted Job.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord turned the captivity of Job, when he prayed for his friends: also the Lord gave Job twice as much as he had before.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then came there unto him all his brethren, and all his sisters, and all they that had been of his acquaintance before, and did eat bread with him in his house: and they bemoaned him, and comforted him over all the evil that the Lord had brought upon him: every man also gave him a piece of money, and every one an earring of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord blessed the latter end of Job more than his beginning: for he had fourteen thousand sheep, and six thousand camels, and a thousand yoke of oxen, and a thousand she asses.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had also seven sons and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he called the name of the first, Jemima; and the name of the second, Kezia; and the name of the third, Keren-happuch.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in all the land were no women found so fair as the daughters of Job: and their father gave them inheritance among their brethren.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this lived Job an hundred and forty years, and saw his sons, and his sons’ sons, even four generations.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Job died, being old and full of days.
speaker: Narrator
